Saudi Arabia forbids live broadcasts of tarawih prayers from the mosque for any media platform. Photo/Hani Alshaer/Anadolu Agency
RIYADH – The Saudi government has issued a new directive that prohibits the live broadcast of Tarawih Salat from the mosque for any media platform.
The ban was presented by the Ministry of Islamic Affairs, Preaching, and Guidance of Saudi Arabia, as published by the Government News; Saudi Press Agency (SPA) on Wednesday.
According to the ministry, the kingdom also banned the use of cameras in the mosque to record priests and worshipers during prayers, including tarawih evening prayers during Ramadan.
The ministry stated that these steps aim to maintain the sanctity of the mosque and maintain an appropriate atmosphere for worship, ensuring that pilgrims are not disturbed.
The ministry also emphasized the importance of priests and speakers to adhere to the ministry’s guidelines and guide the congregation to adhere to the right ethics in the mosque.
In addition, the ministry stressed that the collection of financial contributions to hold the iftar pilgrims at the mosque was not permitted.
If the iftar pilgrims are held, it must be held in the area specified under the supervision of the relevant authority, while ensuring compliance with health and safety steps.
Ramadan in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia is estimated to begin on February 27 to March 29, 2025.
